nodes.text: Absolute intergenerational income mobility in the United States has declined substantially since 1940 and this decline is driven mainly by a more unequal distribution of economic growth rather than by lower aggregate GDP growth alone
Absolute mobility (fraction of children earning more than their parents) fell from about 92% for the 1940 birth cohort to about 50% for the 1980s cohorts
Most of the decline is due to a more unequal distribution of GDP growth across income groups; redistributing growth as in the 1940 cohort would reverse over 70% of the decline

Increasing aggregate GDP growth without changing the current distribution of growth has limited effects: under today's distribution one would need sustained real per-family GDP growth above about 5% per year (total GDP above about 6.4%) to restore mid-20th century mobility rates
Method: Combined marginal income distributions for parents and children with the copula (joint distribution of parent and child income ranks) to compute absolute mobility by cohort
Result: Under the copula-stability benchmark (applying 1980-82 copula to earlier cohorts) estimated average absolute mobility declined from 92% (1940 cohort) to 50% (1984 cohort)
Counterfactual result: Allocating 2010 GDP across households as in the 1940 cohort (more broadly shared growth) raises absolute mobility for the 1980 cohort to about 80% (closing ~71% of the decline)

Counterfactual result: Increasing GDP growth to 2.5% per working-age family from 1980 to 2010 (higher-growth scenario) but keeping 2010 distribution yields mean absolute mobility of about 62% for the 1980 cohort (closing ~29% of the gap)

Evidence: Simulations show unequal distribution of growth concentrates gains among high-income households so aggregate growth alone yields small increases in the share of children who out-earn their parents

Data: Marginal child income distributions from CPS (March supplements 1970-2014) and parents' income distributions from pooled decennial census IPUMS samples (1940-2000); copula estimated using de-identified tax records for 1980-82 cohorts (over 10 million pairs)

Technical method: For cohorts before 1980 used (i) copula-stability benchmark and (ii) linear programming to compute tight upper and lower bounds over all copulas satisfying first-order stochastic dominance constraints

Evidence: Bounds on absolute mobility are very tight for early cohorts (e.g., 1940 cohort bounded 84% to 98%) because child and parent marginal distributions were widely separated, but bounds widen for recent cohorts due to greater overlap

Sensitivity: Results are robust to alternative inflation deflators, measuring income at age 40, including taxes and transfers, adjusting for family size, and plausible upward adjustments to reported child incomes

Heterogeneity: Declines in absolute mobility occurred in all 50 states and across genders for family-income comparisons; individual-level comparisons show larger decline for sons versus fathers and rising female labor force participation affects females' patterns

Assumptions and limitations: Copula stability is assumed as a benchmark and bounded otherwise; parents with zero or negative income are treated separately; inability to observe race in tax copula prevents race-specific heterogeneity analysis
